Around 2:30 PM, Gage\'s troops were ambushed, causing the terrified redcoats to break ranks and retreat in confusion. Braddock and other officers tried to calm the men but failed. The British officers, except for Washington, were either wounded or killed. Colonial troops attempted to fight the French on their own terms in the woods but were mistakenly fired upon by their British allies. Despite the defeat being one of the worst in British colonial history, Washington emerged as a "bullet proof hero of the Monongahela."']

His leadership during this campaign and subsequent decision to resign and return to Mount Vernon in early 1759 marked the end of his military service in the war and the beginning of his life as a landowner and public figure.']
